materials.raw_text:
B (Boron) - 0.6 g
Er (Erbium) - 0.1 g
Ni (Nickel) - 21 g
Ti (Titanium) - 1 g
Base Material (e.g., epoxy resin) - 300 g

sourcing.instructions:
B - Specialty chemical suppliers or online chemical retailers
Er - Rare earth material suppliers
Ni - Metal suppliers or online retailers
Ti - Metal suppliers
Base Material - Craft or hardware stores
steps: B - Specialty chemical suppliers or online chemical retailers
Ni - Metal suppliers or online retailers
Base Material - Craft or hardware stores
2. In a clean, dry container, mix the 0.6 g of boron and 0.1 g of erbium thoroughly.
3. Add 21 g of nickel to the mixture and blend well.
4. Finally, incorporate the 1 g of titanium and mix until uniform.
5. Gradually add 300 g of the base material while continuing to mix to ensure an even distribution of the metallic powders.
preparation.raw_text:
1. Measure and gather all materials.
2. In a clean, dry container, mix the 0.6 g of boron and 0.1 g of erbium thoroughly.
3. Add 21 g of nickel to the mixture and blend well.
4. Finally, incorporate the 1 g of titanium and mix until uniform.
5. Gradually add 300 g of the base material while continuing to mix to ensure an even distribution of the metallic powders.

steps: 1. Place the mixed materials in a suitable mold for the dimensions 3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches.
2. Heat in a furnace at 1200°C for 2 hours to promote bonding and fusion of the materials.
heating.raw_text:
1. Place the mixed materials in a suitable mold for the dimensions 3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches.
2. Heat in a furnace at 1200°C for 2 hours to promote bonding and fusion of the materials.

steps: 1. Allow the material to cool gradually within the furnace to room temperature over a period of 4 hours. Do not open the furnace during this time to avoid thermal shock.
cooling.raw_text: 1. Allow the material to cool gradually within the furnace to room temperature over a period of 4 hours. Do not open the furnace during this time to avoid thermal shock.

steps: 1. Once cooled, remove the solid sample from the mold.
2. Inspect for any surface imperfections and use fine-grit sandpaper to smooth out rough edges.
3. Optionally, apply a protective sealant to enhance durability, following the manufacturer's instructions for application and curing time.
post_processing.raw_text:
1. Once cooled, remove the solid sample from the mold.
2. Inspect for any surface imperfections and use fine-grit sandpaper to smooth out rough edges.
3. Optionally, apply a protective sealant to enhance durability, following the manufacturer's instructions for application and curing time.
